nodes.name: Isaac Newton
nodes.tooltip: Formulated the laws of motion and universal gravitation, foundational in classical mechanics. His work in optics and calculus also laid the groundwork for modern physics and mathematics.

nodes.name: Franciscus Sylvius
nodes.tooltip: Physician and anatomist, regarded as one of the founders of modern clinical medicine and chemical pathology. His work on the circulation of the blood and brain anatomy was pioneering.

nodes.name: Martinus Schoock
nodes.tooltip: Dutch scholar and prolific writer known for his work in philosophy, theology, and science. He wrote against René Descartes, contributing to debates on Cartesian philosophy.

nodes.name: John Gough
nodes.tooltip: British mathematician and physicist, blind from infancy, who contributed to the understanding of elasticity and thermodynamics. Mentored John Dalton, influencing atomic theory.

nodes.name: John Cranke
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and philosopher, known for his work in mathematical logic and early contributions to calculus.

nodes.name: Gottfried Möbius
nodes.tooltip: Known for contributions to projective geometry and topology, including the Möbius strip, a non-orientable surface. His work continues to be a cornerstone in mathematical topology and physics.

nodes.name: Johann von Brunn
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and astronomer, contributed to early studies in geometry and celestial mechanics. His work laid groundwork for modern astronomical calculations.

nodes.name: Gerardus Leonardus Blasius
nodes.tooltip: Physician and anatomist, contributed to early studies in human anatomy and comparative anatomy. Authored influential medical texts that shaped clinical teaching.

nodes.name: Johann Sturm
nodes.tooltip: Philosopher, mathematician, and educator, known for his contributions to early modern geometry and his efforts to reform educational systems.

nodes.name: Friedrich Ludwig Stegmann
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician known for contributions to differential geometry and the theory of surfaces. His work influenced later studies in mathematical analysis and topology.

nodes.name: Edward Waring
nodes.tooltip: British mathematician known for Waring's Problem in number theory, which relates to sums of powers of integers. His work also contributed to algebra and analysis.

nodes.name: Thomas Bennett
nodes.tooltip: Researcher in computational fluid dynamics, with contributions to modeling complex fluid systems and industrial applications.

nodes.name: Philip Langman
nodes.tooltip: Known for contributions to material science, focusing on the behavior of advanced composites under stress.

nodes.name: Jonathan Stone
nodes.tooltip: Researcher in applied mathematics, working on numerical analysis techniques for engineering problems.

nodes.name: Simon Trasler
nodes.tooltip: Specialist in the field of robotics and automation, with a focus on machine learning applications.

nodes.name: Barry Welch
nodes.tooltip: Applied mathematician studying optimization algorithms for industrial processes.

nodes.name: Paul Boasman
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician focusing on nonlinear dynamics and chaos theory with applications in physics and engineering.

nodes.name: Bernard Buxton
nodes.tooltip: Early contributor to computer vision and pattern recognition; developed foundational algorithms for image analysis.

nodes.name: Mark Dennis
nodes.tooltip: Theoretical physicist and mathematician known for studies in topological optics, including polarization singularities.

nodes.name: Anthony Enfield
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician with contributions to applied mathematics and fluid dynamics, focusing on boundary layer theory.

nodes.name: Christopher Howls
nodes.tooltip: Expert in asymptotic analysis and its applications to wave propagation and quantum mechanics.

nodes.name: Michael Jeffrey
nodes.tooltip: Researcher in applied mathematics, focusing on nonsmooth dynamical systems and their applications in engineering.

nodes.name: Mike Jeffrey
nodes.tooltip: Known for contributions to singular perturbation theory and its applications to real-world systems.

nodes.name: Jonathan Keating
nodes.tooltip: Research in random matrix theory and quantum chaos, bridging connections between number theory and physics.

nodes.name: Zinaida Lewis
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician specializing in fluid mechanics and turbulence, contributing to theoretical and computational models.

nodes.name: Richard Lim
nodes.tooltip: Researcher in applied mathematics, with a focus on numerical analysis and its applications in physics and engineering.

nodes.name: Raul Mondragon
nodes.tooltip: Expert in complex networks and their applications in telecommunication systems and biological modeling.

nodes.name: Kathleen Mount
nodes.tooltip: Known for studies in mathematical biology, particularly in modeling ecological systems and population dynamics.

nodes.name: Jenny Nelson
nodes.tooltip: Physicist and applied mathematician known for her work in renewable energy, particularly modeling photovoltaic devices.

nodes.name: Duncan O'Dell
nodes.tooltip: Theoretical physicist specializing in quantum optics and the study of Bose-Einstein condensates.

nodes.name: Alfredo Ozorio de Almeida
nodes.tooltip: Pioneer in quantum chaos and semiclassical mechanics, with work influencing the intersection of physics and dynamical systems.

nodes.name: Philip Richens
nodes.tooltip: Researcher in theoretical physics, with contributions to statistical mechanics and its applications to material science.

nodes.name: Euan Sinclair
nodes.tooltip: Expert in mathematical finance, particularly in derivatives pricing and risk management.

nodes.name: Colin Upstill
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician focused on wave dynamics and its applications in engineering and geophysics.

nodes.name: Michael Wilkinson
nodes.tooltip: Theoretical physicist studying stochastic processes and chaos theory in physical systems.

nodes.name: Francis Wright
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician specializing in partial differential equations and their applications in engineering and physics.

nodes.name: Michael Berry
nodes.tooltip: Known for Berry phase, a geometric phase in quantum mechanics with applications in many areas of physics. His contributions extend to semiclassical physics and optics, influencing modern theoretical physics.

nodes.name: Oscar Buneman
nodes.tooltip: Pioneer in computational physics and plasma physics, known for the Buneman instability in plasma dynamics.

nodes.name: John Crank
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physicist known for developing the Crank-Nicolson method, a numerical solution for heat transfer equations.

nodes.name: Robert Dingle
nodes.tooltip: Theoretical physicist known for his work in quantum theory and its applications in solid-state physics.

nodes.name: Charlotte Fischer
nodes.tooltip: Developed the multi-configuration Hartree-Fock method, a significant contribution to computational quantum chemistry.

nodes.name: Aaron Klug
nodes.tooltip: Biophysicist awarded the Nobel Prize for his work on crystallographic electron microscopy and nucleic acid-protein complexes.

nodes.name: Donald Leigh
nodes.tooltip: Physicist and mathematician who contributed to the development of computational methods in theoretical physics.

nodes.name: David Mayers
nodes.tooltip: Expert in theoretical computer science, particularly quantum computing and cryptography.

nodes.name: Phyllis Nicolson
nodes.tooltip: Co-developer of the Crank-Nicolson method, which is widely used in numerical simulations of partial differential equations.

nodes.name: Arthur Porter
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and engineer known for his contributions to control theory and its applications to engineering systems.

nodes.name: E. Ridley
nodes.tooltip: Physicist specializing in semiconductor physics, particularly the quantum mechanical properties of materials.

nodes.name: Douglas Rayner Hartree
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physicist known for the Hartree approximation in quantum mechanics and early work in computational methods.

nodes.name: Edgar Appleyard
nodes.tooltip: Physicist known for work in X-ray crystallography, contributing to understanding of atomic structures.

nodes.name: Leslie Bates
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physicist, contributed to early studies in quantum mechanics and atomic structure.

nodes.name: Patrick Blackett
nodes.tooltip: Physicist awarded the Nobel Prize for his work in cosmic rays and bubble chamber techniques.

nodes.name: James Chadwick
nodes.tooltip: Discovered the neutron, pivotal for the development of nuclear physics and atomic theory. This discovery enabled advancements in quantum mechanics and nuclear energy.

nodes.name: John Cockcroft
nodes.tooltip: Nobel laureate in physics for pioneering the first artificial nuclear reaction using a particle accelerator.

nodes.name: Ralph Fowler
nodes.tooltip: Made significant contributions to statistical mechanics, quantum theory, and astrophysics.

nodes.name: Hans Geiger
nodes.tooltip: Co-inventor of the Geiger counter, essential for detecting and measuring radiation, and contributed to atomic theory.

nodes.name: Ernest Marsden
nodes.tooltip: Known for the Rutherford-Marsden experiment, which discovered the atomic nucleus.

nodes.name: Alexander McAulay
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physicist, contributed to optics and the theory of refraction in crystals.

nodes.name: Philip Moon
nodes.tooltip: Physicist known for contributions to nuclear physics and work on the design of particle accelerators.

nodes.name: Marcus Oliphant
nodes.tooltip: Played a key role in the development of radar and nuclear weapons; worked on the Manhattan Project.

nodes.name: Cecil Powell
nodes.tooltip: Nobel laureate for his development of the photographic method to study nuclear processes and discovery of the pion.

nodes.name: Henry Smyth
nodes.tooltip: Known for contributions to atmospheric physics and pioneering studies of ionospheric propagation.

nodes.name: Ernest Walton
nodes.tooltip: Nobel laureate for his work with Cockcroft on the first artificial nuclear reaction.

nodes.name: Edward Appleton
nodes.tooltip: Nobel laureate for his work on the ionosphere, enabling advances in radio wave propagation.

nodes.name: Niels Bohr
nodes.school: Københavns Universitet and University of Cambridge
nodes.tooltip: Developed the Bohr model of the atom and made foundational contributions to quantum theory and atomic structure.

nodes.name: William Bragg
nodes.tooltip: Co-winner of the Nobel Prize for his work in X-ray crystallography, which revealed the structure of crystals.

nodes.name: Robert Ditchburn
nodes.tooltip: Expert in optical physics, contributed to advancements in lens design and light scattering theory.

nodes.name: Arthur Hughes
nodes.tooltip: Known for studies in experimental physics, particularly X-ray diffraction and its applications.

nodes.name: Paul Langevin
nodes.tooltip: Physicist renowned for his work in magnetism and development of Langevin dynamics in statistical mechanics.

nodes.name: John McLennan
nodes.tooltip: Physicist known for pioneering studies in spectroscopy and molecular structure.

nodes.name: Władysław Natanson
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physicist, contributed to thermodynamics and the statistical interpretation of entropy.

nodes.name: Owen Richardson
nodes.tooltip: Nobel laureate for his work on thermionic emission, known as Richardson's law.

nodes.name: Geoffrey Taylor
nodes.tooltip: Fluid dynamicist known for Taylor vortices and his work on turbulence and wave propagation.

nodes.name: George Thomson
nodes.tooltip: Nobel laureate for his discovery of the wave properties of the electron.

nodes.name: John Townsend
nodes.tooltip: Known for work in ionization and gas discharge phenomena, foundational in plasma physics.

nodes.name: Richard Whiddington
nodes.tooltip: Physicist specializing in thermionic emission and the study of X-ray diffraction.

nodes.name: Charles Wilson
nodes.tooltip: Nobel laureate for the invention of the cloud chamber, a tool critical for particle physics.

nodes.name: Harold Wilson
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physicist known for contributions to the understanding of electromagnetic theory.

nodes.name: Jagadish Bose
nodes.tooltip: Pioneering physicist and biologist, made significant contributions to the development of wireless communication.

nodes.name: Joseph Thomson
nodes.tooltip: Discovered the electron, revolutionizing atomic theory and experimental physics.

nodes.name: Ernest Rutherford
nodes.tooltip: Pioneer of nuclear physics, discovered the nucleus and developed the concept of radioactive half-life.

nodes.name: Michael Foster
nodes.tooltip: A pioneer in modern physiology, contributed to the foundation of experimental biology in the UK.

nodes.name: Thomas Huxley
nodes.tooltip: Darwin's Bulldog, renowned for advocating evolutionary biology and his work in comparative anatomy.

nodes.name: William McKenzie
nodes.tooltip: Botanist and pioneer in plant taxonomy, contributing to the classification of flora in Europe.

nodes.name: Philipp von Walther
nodes.tooltip: Renowned ophthalmologist, made significant advancements in eye surgery and clinical methodology.

nodes.name: Georg Beer
nodes.tooltip: Noted for contributions to ophthalmology and surgical techniques related to cataracts.

nodes.name: Joseph Barth
nodes.tooltip: Ophthalmologist and professor, advanced medical training in eye surgery in the Habsburg Monarchy.

nodes.name: Nikolaus von Jacquin
nodes.tooltip: Botanist, chemist, and physician, made significant contributions to natural history and plant taxonomy.

nodes.name: Anton von Störck
nodes.tooltip: Pioneer in experimental medicine, studied the effects of various plants and toxins on human health.

nodes.name: Johann Amman
nodes.tooltip: Botanist known for his work in plant classification and studies of Russian flora.

nodes.name: Edward Barry
nodes.tooltip: Medical practitioner and writer, contributed to early medical texts on surgery and anatomy.

nodes.name: Johann Bohl
nodes.tooltip: Physician and educator, known for his contributions to the advancement of clinical medicine.

nodes.name: Matthias Boretius
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physician, focused on advancing the use of mathematical techniques in medicine.

nodes.name: William Brownrigg
nodes.tooltip: Physician and chemist known for discovering the medical applications of carbon dioxide.

nodes.name: William Cadogan
nodes.tooltip: Physician known for early contributions to public health, advocating for changes in infant feeding practices to prevent rickets.

nodes.name: Nathaniel Cotton
nodes.tooltip: Physician and poet, noted for his contributions to mental health care and the humane treatment of patients.

nodes.name: Thomas Dale
nodes.tooltip: Physician and writer, contributed to early medical education and the advancement of clinical methods.

nodes.name: Johannes de Gorter
nodes.tooltip: Renowned for work in internal medicine and pioneering studies on the lymphatic system.

nodes.name: Julien de La Mettrie
nodes.school: Universiteit Leiden and Université de Reims
nodes.tooltip: Philosopher and physician, known for L'Homme Machine, promoting materialist philosophy in understanding human physiology.

nodes.name: Hieronymus Gaubius
nodes.tooltip: Pioneer in clinical chemistry, authored significant works on chemical principles in medicine.

nodes.name: Johannes Gronovius
nodes.tooltip: Botanist and naturalist, contributed to plant taxonomy and was an early supporter of Carl Linnaeus.

nodes.name: Augustus Hugo
nodes.tooltip: Anatomist and physician known for early work in comparative anatomy and medical education.

nodes.name: John Innes
nodes.school: Universiteit Leiden and Università degli Studi di Padova
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physicist who worked on hydrodynamics and early fluid mechanics.

nodes.name: Alexander Monro
nodes.tooltip: Anatomist and medical educator, foundational in establishing Edinburgh as a center for anatomical research.

nodes.name: Henry Pemberton
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physician, collaborated with Isaac Newton on the third edition of Principia Mathematica.

nodes.name: Andrew Plummer
nodes.tooltip: Physician and chemist, contributed to early pharmacology and the preparation of chemical medicines.

nodes.name: John Pringle
nodes.tooltip: Father of Military Medicine, introduced antiseptic practices and contributed to public health reform.

nodes.name: John Rutherford
nodes.school: Universiteit Leiden and Université de Reims
nodes.tooltip: Physician, instrumental in advancing clinical teaching and bedside medicine in Scotland.

nodes.name: Johann Sömmerring
nodes.tooltip: Anatomist and physician, discovered the macula lutea in the eye and made important contributions to comparative anatomy.

nodes.name: Andrew St Clair (Sinclair)
nodes.tooltip: Physician and naturalist, contributed to the study of botany and early ecological systems.

nodes.name: Pieter van Musschenbroek
nodes.tooltip: Physicist and inventor of the Leyden jar, a precursor to the modern capacitor.

nodes.name: Adriaan van Royen
nodes.tooltip: Botanist known for his work on plant taxonomy, including contributions to the classification of orchids.

nodes.name: Gerard van Swieten
nodes.tooltip: Physician and reformer, brought modern clinical teaching to Vienna and advanced public health systems.

nodes.name: Albrecht von Haller
nodes.tooltip: Father of Modern Physiology, made significant contributions to botany, anatomy, and medicine.

nodes.name: Frederik Winter
nodes.tooltip: Physician known for his contributions to medical education and early work in pharmacology.

nodes.name: Valentinus Baumgartus
nodes.tooltip: Physician and chemist, contributed to early chemical techniques in medicine.

nodes.name: Herman Boerhaave
nodes.tooltip: Influential physician and botanist, regarded as the founder of clinical teaching and modern medical ethics.

nodes.name: Johannes Bruno
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and philosopher, contributed to early Cartesian philosophy and mechanics.

nodes.name: Gysbert Casembroot
nodes.tooltip: Physician known for advancements in surgery and medical education.

nodes.name: Paulus Derecskei
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and astronomer, contributed to early studies in celestial mechanics and planetary motion.

nodes.name: Jacobus Erckelens
nodes.tooltip: Physician known for his work in anatomy and contributions to comparative studies in animal physiology.

nodes.name: Johannes Helvetius
nodes.tooltip: Physician and chemist, known for his studies on medicinal chemistry and pharmacology.

nodes.name: Simon Hoet
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and natural philosopher, focused on early developments in calculus and mechanics.

nodes.name: Sámuel Köleséri
nodes.tooltip: Physician and historian, known for his work on mineralogy and early geological surveys.

nodes.name: Bernard Mandeville
nodes.tooltip: Physician and philosopher, famous for The Fable of the Bees, which explored societal and economic behavior.

nodes.name: Esaias Rouxel
nodes.tooltip: Chemist and physician, contributed to early studies in medical chemistry and drug formulations.

nodes.name: Hermannus Schuyl
nodes.tooltip: Physician and anatomist, contributed to studies of human anatomy and surgical practices.

nodes.name: Joseph Serrurier
nodes.tooltip: Physician and early advocate of preventive medicine, focused on public health measures.

nodes.name: Henricus van Bronchorst
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and astronomer, worked on early celestial mechanics and lunar studies.

nodes.name: Pontianus van der Codde
nodes.tooltip: Philosopher and theologian, contributed to debates on Cartesianism and early modern philosophy.

nodes.name: Paulus von der Lahr
nodes.tooltip: Physician and natural philosopher, made early contributions to mineralogy and geology.

nodes.name: Michaël Wariensis
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician known for advancing geometrical techniques in architecture and engineering.

nodes.name: Fredericus Westhovius
nodes.tooltip: Botanist and physician, contributed to the classification of medicinal plants.

nodes.name: Daniel Arens
nodes.tooltip: Physician and chemist, focused on experimental methods in chemical medicine.

nodes.name: Sibertus Coeman
nodes.tooltip: Anatomist and physician, advanced clinical techniques in human dissection.

nodes.name: Petrus Fucschius
nodes.tooltip: Physician and natural philosopher, explored early connections between chemistry and medicine.

nodes.name: Hubertus Leydekker
nodes.tooltip: Physician and anatomist, known for detailed anatomical illustrations used in medical education.

nodes.name: Petrus Tielenius
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and theologian, contributed to early studies in combinatorics and probability.

nodes.name: Jacobus Witte
nodes.tooltip: Physician specializing in the treatment of infectious diseases and public health measures.

nodes.name: Reinier de Graaf
nodes.tooltip: Physician and anatomist, known for discovering ovarian follicles (Graafian follicles).

nodes.name: Frederick Dekkers
nodes.tooltip: Physician and early pioneer in clinical diagnostics, focused on using urine analysis for medical assessment.

nodes.name: Burchard de Volder
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physicist, known for introducing experimental physics into university curricula.

nodes.name: Lucas Schacht
nodes.tooltip: Theologian and philosopher, contributed to early debates on Cartesianism and scholasticism.

nodes.name: Florentius Schuyl
nodes.tooltip: Physician and philosopher, known for translating and disseminating the works of René Descartes.

nodes.name: Robert Sibbald
nodes.tooltip: Co-founder of the Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh, contributed to early Scottish medicine.

nodes.name: Johannes Swammerdam
nodes.tooltip: Pioneering entomologist and microscopist, known for his detailed studies of insect anatomy.

nodes.name: Johann von Flammerdinge
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician, focused on early geometry and contributions to celestial mechanics.

nodes.name: Ehrenfried von Tschirnhaus
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and inventor, developed the process for manufacturing porcelain in Europe.

nodes.name: Georg Wedel
nodes.tooltip: Physician and chemist, contributed to early pharmacological studies and clinical education.

nodes.name: Johannes de Bruyn
nodes.tooltip: Physician known for advancements in medical diagnostics and early studies of human physiology.

nodes.name: Matthias Nethenus
nodes.tooltip: Theologian and philosopher, contributed to discussions on Cartesian metaphysics and theology.

nodes.name: Lambertus van Velthuysen
nodes.tooltip: Philosopher and theologian, known for integrating Cartesian principles with Christian theology.

nodes.name: Daniel Berckringer
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician focused on early geometry and algebraic methods.

nodes.name: George Darwin
nodes.tooltip: Astronomer, known for theories on tidal evolution and the formation of the moon.

nodes.name: John Hopkinson
nodes.tooltip: Electrical engineer and physicist, contributed to early studies of magnetic properties in circuits.

nodes.name: Joseph Larmor
nodes.tooltip: Theoretical physicist, known for contributions to electromagnetism and the Larmor precession.

nodes.name: Robert Rumsey Webb
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and educator, contributed to early research in hydrodynamics.

nodes.name: Alfred Whitehead
nodes.tooltip: Co-author of Principia Mathematica, foundational work in mathematical logic and philosophy.

nodes.name: George Chrystal
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician known for his work on algebra and contributions to the theory of electricity.

nodes.name: Horace Lamb
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physicist, made significant contributions to fluid dynamics and wave theory.

nodes.name: John Strutt (Lord Rayleigh)
nodes.tooltip: Nobel laureate for discoveries in acoustics and the properties of gases, including Rayleigh scattering.

nodes.name: Arthur Cayley
nodes.school: Universiteit Leiden, University College Dublin, and University of Oxford
nodes.tooltip: One of the founders of modern algebra, known for Cayley-Hamilton theorem and matrix theory.

nodes.name: Sir Francis Galton
nodes.tooltip: Pioneered studies in statistics, psychology, and eugenics; known for inventing the concept of correlation.

nodes.name: James Maxwell
nodes.tooltip: Formulated Maxwell's equations, unifying electromagnetism; foundational work in statistical mechanics.

nodes.name: George Stokes
nodes.tooltip: Physicist and mathematician, known for Navier-Stokes equations and contributions to fluid dynamics.

nodes.name: Peter Tait
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physicist, known for work on knot theory and thermodynamics.

nodes.name: William Thomson (Lord Kelvin)
nodes.tooltip: Physicist known for the absolute temperature scale (Kelvin) and work in thermodynamics.

nodes.name: Isaac Todhunter
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and historian of mathematics, known for his textbooks in calculus and mechanics.

nodes.name: William Hopkins
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and geologist, made contributions to the study of glaciers and the Earth's interior.

nodes.name: John Dawson
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician known for his teaching and popularization of calculus in Britain.

nodes.name: Henry Bracken
nodes.tooltip: Physician known for advancements in public health and sanitation practices.

nodes.name: Adam Sedgwick
nodes.tooltip: Geologist, known for naming the Cambrian system and advancing stratigraphy.

nodes.name: Thomas Postlethwaite
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and educator, contributed to early algebraic methods and academic administration.

nodes.name: Stephen Whisson
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and philosopher, contributed to the development of calculus and its applications.

nodes.name: Walter Taylor
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician known for early work on geometry and the applications of calculus.

nodes.name: James Jurin
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physician, known for early work on fluid mechanics and hydrostatics.

nodes.name: Robert Smith
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and optician, authored A Compleat System of Opticks, advancing the study of light and lenses.

nodes.name: Roger Cotes
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physicist, known for the Cotes' formulas and editing the second edition of Newton's Principia.

nodes.name: John Flamsteed
nodes.tooltip: First Astronomer Royal, known for his detailed star catalog that advanced celestial navigation.

nodes.name: William Whiston
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and theologian, succeeded Newton as Lucasian Professor and advocated for Newtonian principles.

nodes.name: Edward Routh
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician known for contributions to stability theory and mechanics, co-developer of the Routh-Hurwitz criterion.

nodes.name: Augustus De Morgan
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and logician, founder of modern symbolic logic and De Morgan's laws in boolean algebra.

nodes.name: William Whewell
nodes.tooltip: Polymath and philosopher, coined terms like scientist and contributed to mechanics and the history of science.

nodes.name: George Peacock
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and reformer, instrumental in modernizing algebra and university mathematics education.

nodes.name: Thomas Jones
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician known for his contributions to calculus and mechanics in applied mathematics.

nodes.name: Georg Carius
nodes.tooltip: Chemist known for Carius tubes, an apparatus for organic elemental analysis and studies of halogens.

nodes.name: Edward Frankland
nodes.tooltip: Chemist and pioneer in valence theory, known for his work on organometallic compounds.

nodes.name: Guido Goldschmiedt
nodes.tooltip: Organic chemist known for structural determination of natural compounds such as vanillin.

nodes.name: Francis Japp
nodes.tooltip: Chemist known for the Japp-Klingemann reaction, significant in organic synthesis.

nodes.name: A.W. Hermann Kolbe
nodes.tooltip: Chemist who developed the Kolbe synthesis, a method for synthesizing organic acids.

nodes.name: Philipp Lenard
nodes.tooltip: Nobel laureate in physics for research on cathode rays and the photoelectric effect.

nodes.name: Adolf Lieben
nodes.tooltip: Chemist, contributed to the study of organic compounds and developed the Lieben iodometric method.

nodes.name: Carl Ludwig
nodes.tooltip: Physiologist, pioneered modern methods in physiology and developed the kymograph for recording blood pressure.

nodes.name: Lothar Meyer
nodes.tooltip: Chemist, independently developed the periodic classification of the elements alongside Mendeleev.

nodes.name: Viktor Meyer
nodes.tooltip: Chemist, known for inventing the Victor Meyer apparatus for determining vapor densities.

nodes.name: August Streng
nodes.tooltip: Chemist, contributed to studies of inorganic compounds and spectroscopy.

nodes.name: Thomas Thorpe
nodes.tooltip: Chemist, known for his work on atomic weights and thermochemistry.

nodes.name: Johann von Baeyer
nodes.tooltip: Organic chemist, discovered indigo synthesis and won the Nobel Prize for contributions to the dye industry.

nodes.name: Roland von Eötvös
nodes.tooltip: Physicist known for work on gravitation and the Eötvös experiment on the equivalence principle.

nodes.name: Heinrich Weber
nodes.tooltip: Physicist, contributed to thermodynamics and electromagnetic theory.

nodes.name: Robert Bunsen
nodes.tooltip: Chemist, co-developer of the Bunsen burner and pioneer in spectroscopy.

nodes.name: Leopold Gmelin
nodes.tooltip: Chemist, developed the Gmelin test for bile pigments and contributed to the systematic organization of chemistry.

nodes.name: Eilhard Mitscherlich
nodes.tooltip: Chemist, discovered isomorphism and contributed to the development of crystallography.

nodes.name: Georg Hildebrandt
nodes.tooltip: Chemist and physician, contributed to studies on gases and medical chemistry.

nodes.name: Karl von Kielmeyer
nodes.tooltip: Naturalist and physiologist, studied the interconnectedness of animal physiology and evolutionary theories.

nodes.name: Samuel Gmelin
nodes.tooltip: Botanist and explorer, contributed to studies on the flora of Russia and Central Asia.

nodes.name: Phillip Gmelin
nodes.tooltip: Chemist and botanist, advanced studies in natural compounds and plant-based medicine.

nodes.name: Burchard Mauchart
nodes.tooltip: Anatomist and physician, studied the physiology of vision and eye diseases.

nodes.name: Elias Camerarius Jr.
nodes.tooltip: Botanist, discovered the role of pollen in plant reproduction.

nodes.name: Rudolf Camerarius
nodes.tooltip: Botanist known for his studies on plant reproduction, particularly the role of sex in plants.

nodes.name: Elias Camerarius Sr.
nodes.tooltip: Physician and botanist, known for advancing botanical and medical education.

nodes.name: Georg Metzger
nodes.tooltip: Early botanist and physician, contributed to the development of plant taxonomy.

nodes.name: Johann Gmelin
nodes.tooltip: Botanist and explorer, known for his work on the flora of Siberia and Central Asia.

nodes.name: Ferdinand Oetinger
nodes.tooltip: Theologian and philosopher, contributed to early German pietism and mysticism studies.

nodes.name: Michael Alberti
nodes.tooltip: Physician and anatomist, advanced medical education and clinical diagnostics.

nodes.name: Simon Hilscher
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and theologian, worked on early Cartesian interpretations of natural philosophy.

nodes.name: Georg Stahl
nodes.tooltip: Chemist and physician, developed the phlogiston theory in early chemistry.

nodes.name: Rudolf Krause
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and astronomer, focused on celestial mechanics and planetary motion.

nodes.name: Friedrich Stromeyer
nodes.tooltip: Chemist who discovered the element cadmium and contributed to metallurgy.

nodes.name: Louis Thenard
nodes.tooltip: Chemist known for discovering hydrogen peroxide and his work in organic chemistry.

nodes.name: Nicolas Vauquelin
nodes.tooltip: Chemist who discovered chromium and beryllium, contributing to the study of rare elements.

nodes.name: Antoine de Fourcroy
nodes.tooltip: Chemist and physician, instrumental in the development of chemical nomenclature.

nodes.name: Jean Bucquet
nodes.tooltip: Chemist and physician, focused on chemical processes in digestion and metabolism.

nodes.name: Pierre Macquer
nodes.tooltip: Chemist, known for Macquer’s dictionary of chemistry and contributions to dye chemistry.

nodes.name: Guillaume-Francois Rouelle
nodes.tooltip: Chemist, introduced the term base in chemistry and advanced acid-base theories.

nodes.name: Johann Spitzley
nodes.tooltip: Early botanist and horticulturist, contributed to studies of plant physiology.

nodes.name: Nicolas Lemery
nodes.tooltip: Chemist, known for his textbook on chemistry and contributions to acid-base theories.

nodes.name: David Algoewer
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician, contributed to early developments in geometry and algebra.

nodes.name: Johann Doppelmayr
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician, astronomer, and cartographer, known for his celestial maps.

nodes.name: Christoph Glaser
nodes.tooltip: Chemist, contributed to early alchemical methods and medicinal chemistry.

nodes.name: Martin Knorr
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician, focused on algebra and its applications to early mechanics.

nodes.name: Johann Müller
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and physicist, contributed to optics and wave theory.

nodes.name: Leonhard Sturm
nodes.school: Europa-Universität Viadrina Frankfurt an der Oder
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and architect, contributed to structural engineering and mechanics.

nodes.name: Johann Wagner
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician, focused on geometry and its practical applications in surveying.

nodes.name: Alexander William Bickerton
nodes.tooltip: Physicist and theorist, contributed to the development of chemical kinetics and astronomical models.

nodes.name: Thomas Hirst
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician, known for contributions to algebra and geometry.

nodes.name: John Tyndall
nodes.tooltip: Physicist, known for work on light scattering (Tyndall effect) and the study of glaciers.
